An old banker used RSA, but chose a modulus that's the product of two Blum primes. Now their secret message is encrypted as 914399414497286782875135684385031431509314494236145931365900879354596375380085669992508455955421041780188223324024610053417318759166049379059303889329387—can you break it?

The flag format is flag{...}
n=4773202298505231976109645863907272146231464856245124140985306192142493843684996189657049666821613201463293582483328288896054254953546912284340857216213569, e=3709452242362047210976815417261701723225710814352613898906892792468091338968065583642427891848439645023511098686648874468839911086135607331410351857909449
The lower 104 bits of p are: 31968044665629192779644561956204385359


---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{mss2qm39}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 914399414497286782875135684385031431509314494236145931365900879354596375380085669992508455955421041780188223324024610053417318759166049379059303889329387
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=4773202298505231976109645863907272146231464856245124140985306192142493843684996189657049666821613201463293582483328288896054254953546912284340857216213569, e=3709452242362047210976815417261701723225710814352613898906892792468091338968065583642427891848439645023511098686648874468839911086135607331410351857909449
The lower 104 bits of p are: 31968044665629192779644561956204385359

extra_info: p=70773260129147515868059452155995974698799941507089190231169710640256909775951, q=67443583774367051488242594501222741462576056014709743086276824181074409745519, φ(n)=4773202298505231976109645863907272146231464856245124140985306192142493843684857972813146152254256899416636363767166912898532456020229465749519525896692100
subtype: blum_integers
archetype: rsa
